message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Pompe disease, which is caused by a deficiency of lysosomal alpha 1,4-glucosidase. This deficiency impairs the breakdown of glycogen in muscle cells, leading to muscle weakness and cardiomyopathy. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency causes von Gierke disease, debranching enzyme deficiency causes Cori disease, and branching enzyme deficiency causes Andersen disease, which may present with hypotonia but not cardiomyopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of electron dense granules within the lysosomes and a defect in glycogen processing suggest Pompe disease, which is caused by a deficiency of lysosomal alpha 1,4-glucosidase. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency causes glycogen storage disease type I, debranching enzyme deficiency causes glycogen storage disease type III, and branching enzyme deficiency causes glycogen storage disease type IV, but none of these diseases present with all the symptoms described in the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms point towards glycogen storage disease (GSD) type II, also known as Pompe disease. Electron dense granules found within lysosomes suggest lysosomal storage disease. GSD type II is caused by a deficiency in lysosomal alpha 1,4-glucosidase. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency leads to GSD type I, debranching enzyme deficiency leads to GSD type III and branching enzyme deficiency leads to GSD type IV.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of electron dense granules within the lysosomes suggests a lysosomal storage disorder, and the family history of childhood onset hypertrophic cardiomyopathy suggests Pompe disease (glycogen storage disease type II). The enzyme responsible for degradation of glycogen within lysosomes is lysosomal alpha 1,4-glucosidase, so the correct answer is (B). Glucose-6-phosphatase is responsible for glycogenolysis in the liver and kidney, not lysosomal degradation. Debranching enzyme and branching enzyme are involved in glycogen synthesis and degradation within the cytoplasm, not lysosomes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and biopsy findings suggest Pompe disease, which is caused by a deficiency in lysosomal alpha 1,4-glucosidase. This leads to the buildup of glycogen within cells, resulting in the symptoms seen in this patient. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency leads to Von Gierke's disease, while debranching enzyme and branching enzyme deficiencies lead to other glycogen storage diseases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest glycogen storage disease, specifically Pompe disease, which is caused by a deficiency in lysosomal alpha 1,4-glucosidase, also known as acid maltase. The electron dense granules in the biopsy confirm this diagnosis. None of the other options are associated with Pompe disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including respiratory distress, failure to thrive, and an enlarged heart, suggest that the patient has Pompe disease, a glycogen storage disease caused by a deficiency in lysosomal alpha 1,4-glucosidase. The electron dense granules in the biopsy support this theory. None of the other options are associated with Pompe disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The electron dense granules within the lysosomes suggest Pompe disease, which is caused by a deficiency in lysosomal alpha 1,4-glucosidase. The symptoms, including hypotonia, failure to thrive, and enlarged heart, are also consistent with this diagnosis. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency causes Von Gierke disease, debranching enzyme deficiency causes Andersen disease, and branching enzyme deficiency causes Krabbe disease, none of which are consistent with this patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and the electron dense granules within the lysosomes suggest a lysosomal storage disorder. The family history of childhood onset hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and a deficiency in glycogen processing suggest Pompe disease, which is caused by a deficiency in lysosomal alpha 1,4-glucosidase. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency causes von Gierke disease while Debranching enzyme deficiency and Branching enzyme deficiency cause glycogen storage diseases type III and type IV, respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The electron dense granules within the lysosomes suggest glycogen storage disease type II, also known as Pompe disease, which is caused by a deficiency in lysosomal alpha 1,4-glucosidase enzyme. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of glycogen within lysosomes, which can cause cardiac and skeletal muscle problems.
